title: Jon Snow - Not ours
body:
Just consulting the appendix of Storm: 

For House Stark:  JON SNOW, a Sworn Brother of the Night’s Watch,

For the Night’s Watch:  JON SNOW, the Bastard of Winterfell, his steward and squire, lost beyond the Wall.

So both groups define Jon as part of the other group. No real analysis. Just putting it out there.

summary:
Me, a Bisexual: *Watching Game of Thrones by my lonesome*
GOT: *Daenerys and Jon Snow appear on screen together*
Me: YAASSS MY...
body:
Me, a Bisexual: *Watching Game of Thrones by my lonesome*


GOT: *Daenerys and Jon Snow appear on screen together*


Me: YAASSS MY HUSBAND AND MY WIFE!!!


Me: *Trying not to be a stereotype but I literally couldn’t choose between them*

Me: *internally*

Daenerys.

summary:
Jon: What's the best way to kill someone?

Sansa: Kindness!

Arya: If we're being stealthy, potassium cyanide. Otherwise,...
body:
Jon: What’s the best way to kill someone?

Sansa: Kindness!

Arya: If we’re being stealthy, potassium cyanide. Otherwise, anything from a knife to a bazooka works.

a song of ice and fire
summary: Jon's chapter: "And Arya . . . he missed her even more than Robb... Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had . . . yet she...
body:
Jon’s chapter: “And Arya … he missed her even more than Robb… Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had … yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.”

Arya’s chapter: “That was when Arya missed her brothers most. She wanted to tease Bran and play with baby Rickon and have Robb smile at her. She wanted Jon to muss up her hair and call her “little sister” and finish her sentences with her.”

summary: The number of Soldiers each monarch controls in season 7
body:
The number of Soldiers each monarch controls in season 7

Queen Daenerys Targaryen

3 Dragons

100,000 Dothraki (unsure how many are combatents)

8,000 Unsullied (less after sons of the harpy insurgency)

Receives small loses over Season 7

Westeros Houses pledged to her are never of any use

King Jon Snow

Stated to be 20,000 men

Though this is just the forces at Winterfell, the forces that remained in The Vale (untouched throughout the shows run) should easily double this number at least

Receive 0 loses over season 7 (except the 2 red shirts Jon take beyond the wall, check the got wiki for wight hunt)

Queen Cersei Lanniser

After getting repeatedly spanked by Robb Stark the Lannister army has suffered. Tyrion states that the bulk of their forces (10,000 at least) will be at Casterly rock. While this wasnt the case, I think its fair to say that 12,000 would be a high (or at LEAST fair) estimate for the CR forces. And this is stated to be the bulk of their army, meaning well over half. Its fair to say that the Lannister army probably totals at 15,000-16,000 (this is a high estimate).

Receives at least 1,000-2,000 loses during the battle of the goldroad (Lannister forces where spread thin so its unlikely that the whole army was caught in the ambush)

Conclusion

Cersei has by far the smallest army out of the three monarchs. Why does she seem to hold any authority during their parley in Kings Landing, she doesnt have the men to take any significant ground, much less keep it

summary: Any thoughts on whether Jon will become KitN in the books as well? I personally hate the idea. Jon stepping over his siblings’...
question: Any thoughts on whether Jon will become KitN in the books as well? I personally hate the idea. Jon stepping over his siblings’ birthright pretty much proves that Catelyn was right about him. And the death-and-resurrection loophole everyone believes he’ll use to leave the Watch is such a cop-out. Why should anybody believe that? And even if they do, why on earth would anybody follow a zombie in the fight against an army of zombies? Any reasonable person would set Jon on fire just to be safe.
answer:
1. I doubt Jon becomes King in the North in the books; while his name might be in the running as various factions discuss what should happen with Winterfell, I think this also coincides with some pretty heavy post-resurrection apathy on Jon’s part. If it happens, I think Jon would feel a very complicated mixture of emotions - pleasure, and guilt that he can feel happy about such a thing, and very much afraid of what this might mean for Sansa. There will be plenty of internal monologue to show us, yet again, that Catelyn was wrong about him.

2. I think the death-and-resurrection loophole is a transparent rules lawyer device that other Watchmen will use to get rid of Jon after he comes back to life, effectively kicking him off the front lines of the war against the dead and contributing in no small part to the post-resurrection apathy I mentioned that I find likely.

3. Finally, I’m thinking it’s possible that reasonable people will set Jon’s body on fire, just to be safe, and get a nasty shock…

3. Finally, I’m thinking it’s possible that reasonable people will set Jon’s body on fire, just to be safe, and get a nasty shock…

If it happens, I think Jon would feel a very complicated mixture of emotions - pleasure, and guilt that he can feel happy about such a thing, and very much afraid of what this might mean for Sansa. There will be plenty of internal monologue to show us, yet again, that Catelyn was wrong about him.

2. I think the death-and-resurrection loophole is a transparent rules lawyer device that other Watchmen will use to get rid of Jon after he comes back to life, effectively kicking him off the front lines of the war against the dead and contributing in no small part to the post-resurrection apathy I mentioned that I find likely.

3. Finally, I’m thinking it’s possible that reasonable people will set Jon’s body on fire, just to be safe, and get a nasty shock…

If it happens, I think Jon would feel a very complicated mixture of emotions - pleasure, and guilt that he can feel happy about such a thing, and very much afraid of what this might mean for Sansa. There will be plenty of internal monologue to show us, yet again, that Catelyn was wrong about him.

2. 3. Finally, I’m thinking it’s possible that reasonable people will set Jon’s body on fire, just to be safe, and get a nasty shock…

body:
When Ned finds Lyanna

Lyanna: His name… is.. JON CENA!!! -theme song-

Ned: Lyanna you’re literally dead

Lyanna: DEAD ASS AYYYYyyyyy……

Lyanna:

Ned: -looks down to the Baby- … Alright i guess your name is Jon.

summary: I was thinking about Robb and Jon’s first execution ceremony and maybe they wouldn’t be coddled like this afterward, but I just...
caption: I was thinking about Robb and Jon’s first execution ceremony and maybe they wouldn’t be coddled like this afterward, but I just like to cry sometimes and think about how even when he needed it, Jon never had a mother’s comfort but got to see it just out of reach
